results.title: Outdoor cooking in winter
results.creator_credit: Moreland-Latchford Productions, James McCormick and Norman Keziere
results.brief_description: The preparation of a “kitchen area” in a winter wilderness camp is described in detail. Subsistence diets are not an automatic part of roughing it outdoors and here ways are shown of using nature’s natural resources to aid in personal comfort. The preparation of fish and birds for the open fire is shown and the proper method of cooking over an open fire - slowly and turning the meat regularly.

results.title: Outdoor adventure: flying squirrels
results.creator_credit: Kingcroft Productions, Keith Hutchison and William Horne
results.brief_description: Shows a pet flying squirrel, also known as a sugar glider or phalanger, and features several flights of this marsupial. Describes its diet of nuts, nectar and various insects and shows the trees where it lives.

results.title: Outback supply
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Don Murray and David Haythornthwaite
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
John Thomas operates the outback supply truck from Tibooburra northwest NSW. He periodically delivers mail and all types of supplies to people on outlying sheep and cattle stations. Often he takes his four year old son Normie along with him on his mail-run. Cinematography by Dean Semler. Edited by Nick Torrens.

results.title: Outback patrol
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Stanley Hawes and Lee Robinson
results.brief_description: An insight into the life of Constable Robert Darken of the Northern Territory Police Force. Every mid-summer, Constable Darken leaves home for a two to three month turn-around of his beat, several thousand square miles of rugged and barren country of the Territory. Here, he inspects cattle, water towers, mines, registers births and marriages, even acts as postmaster, duties which are a far cry from the usual conception of police duties.

results.title: Outback festivals of Australia
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Peter Dimond and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description: This award winning film records three of the famous festivals held in the Northern Territory each year. Alice Springs is the venue of camel races and the “Henley-on-Todd”, a boating regatta held in a dry creek-bed. Darwin is infamous for its “Beer Can Regatta”, in which all the sea-going racing craft are made entirely from empty beer cans.

results.title: Out: stories of lesbian and gay youth
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Silva Basmajian and David Adkin
results.brief_description: This film explodes some of the myths that provide the foundation for homophobia. It offers insight into the world of several gay and lesbian youth and looks at the people in their lives, identifying some of the difficulties gay youth face. The film attempts to break the damaging silence surrounding sexual orientation and sexual differences.

results.title: Out shopping
results.creator_credit: R.H.R. Productions, Ronald H. Riley and Eric Marquis
results.brief_description: Two housewives go out on a morning’s shopping. Newly married Mrs A does it unthinkingly; mature Mrs B with dkill. The two meet and Mrs A learns some useful tips. Consumer instructional film successfully using a comedy approach avoiding offence to put across the positive message that shopping must be done carefully.

results.title: Out on a limb
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Caroline Leaf and Erik Roberts
results.brief_description: Canadian independent filmmaker and animator Caroline Leaf is most recognised for the animated shorts she created for the National Film Board of Canada. To make her films she prefers alternative methods to the traditional “cell” animation, which she feels is devoid of emotion. “Out on a Limb” is a compilation of her works. In “The Owl Who Married a Goose” (producer, Pierre Moretti) she uses sand to create the the image. With “Entre Deaux Soeurs/Between Two Sisters” (producers, Robert Forget and Yves Leduc)she scratches emulsion from the film stock. In “The Street” (producer, Caroline Leaf), Leaf utilises waterbased tempera colours mixed with oil on milkglass as a medium. Her other films include “The Interview” (producer, David Verall), “I Met a Man” (producer, Caroline Leaf), “The Metamorphosis of Mr Samsa” (producer, Caroline Leaf) and “Hand Crafted Cinema” (producer and director, Erik Roberts), which is a filmed workshop where she talks about her work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Caroline Leaf and Erik Roberts

results.title: Out of wood (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Explores the close relationship between wood sculptor, Gay Hawkes with children of the Swan Hill North Primary School as she leads them towards the integration of the external world with the inner world of their imagination.
